questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with sudden painless loss of vision in the left eye. On examination, the following retinal findings are observed. Please select the most likely diagnosis based on the retinal findings:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)

Feature

Description

Definition

Sudden occlusion of the central retinal artery

Presentation

Sudden painless loss of vision

Retinal Findings

Cherry red spot in the macula

Boxcar or cattle truck appearance of retinal vessels

 

Presence of Hollenhorst plaques or emboli in retinal arteries

Visual Field

Profound visual field loss

Fundus Examination
  • Pale retina with attenuated arterioles
  • Segmental or diffuse retinal whitening
  • Retinal edema or hemorrhages may be present

Fluorescein Angiography
  • Delayed or absent choroidal and retinal arterial filling
  • Delayed retinal venous filling
  • No leakage of dye into the retina

Management
  • Immediate reduction of intraocular pressure
  • Ocular massage
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be used in select cases
  • Treatment of underlying risk factors (e.g., hypertension, diabetes)
  • Poor prognosis for visual recovery

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics inhibits the attachment of transfer RNA (tRNA) amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- T

Inhibit attachment

  • Tetracycline, Tigecycline
  • Block A-site on 30s Ribosomes
  • Inhibits tRNA AA attachment to A-site

Inhibit translocation

 
  • Macrolides: Erythromycin, Azithromycin
  • Clindamycin
  • Streptogramin: Quinpristine + Dalfopristin (30:70)

Inhibit peptide bond

  • Inhibits Peptidyl transferase by attaching on 50s ribosome
  • Chloramphenicol

Inhibit initiation of protein synthesis

 
  • Linezolid
  • Attaches to 23s subunit present on the 50s ribosome
  • Inhibits attachment of Methionine tRNA (Methininie is the first AA to initiate protein synthesis)

Multiple mechanisms

 
  • Aminoglycoside
  • Binds to 30s
  • Inhibits initiation of protein synthesis
  • Misreading of mRNA- Defective AA attaches
  • Inhibit polysome formation (Attachment of ribosomes on mRNA)

questions.text: At which level does the hypopharynx extend inferiorly?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - C6

Nasopharynx/Epipharynx
  • Extends from base of skull to palate 
  • Superior boundary: base of the skull 
  • Inferior boundary: imaginary line through the palate 
Oropharynx 
  • Extends from hard palate to hyoid bone 
  • Superior boundary: imaginary line through the palate 
  • Inferior boundary: imaginary line passing through tip of epiglottis 
Laryngopharynx/Hypopharynx
  • Extends from tip of epiglottis to lower border of cricoid cartilage (C6 vertebrae)
  • Superior boundary: Imaginary line through tip of epiglottis 
  • Inferior boundary: lower border of cricoid cartilage (C6 vertebrae)

questions.text: Match the following: 1 Type I thyroplasty A Shortening of vocal cords 2 Type II thyroplasty B Medialization of vocal cords 3 Type III thyroplasty C Lengthening of vocal cords 4 Type IV thyroplasty D Lateralization of vocal cords
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C:

Type 1 Thyroplasty (Medialization of vocal cords)
  • In type 1 thyroplasty, a window is created in the thyroid cartilage and then an implant (silastic or cartilage) is placed in the paraglottic space. The placement of an implant helps to push the vocal cord in the midline.

Type 2 Thyroplasty (Lateralization of vocal cords)
  • Lateralization of vocal cord is done either by resecting the arytenoid known as arytenoidectomy or via cordectomy (removal of posterior 2/3rd of vocal cords)
  • Kashima’s operation (cordectomy + arytenoidectomy)

 

Type 3 Thyroplasty (Shortening of vocal cords)
  • This procedure is generally done to lower the vocal pitch by creating a window in the thyroid cartilage and thus shortening the vocal cords.
  • Generally done in cases of Puberphonia and in sex–change operation (female to male).

Type 4 Thyroplasty (lengthening of vocal cords)
  • This procedure is done to elevated the vocal pitch.
  • Generally done in cases of androphonia and in sex – change operation.
  • This consists of lengthening the thyroid cartilage which includes cricothyroid approximation

Type I thyroplasty

Medialization of vocal cords

Type II thyroplasty

Lateralization of vocal cords

Type III thyroplasty

Shortening of vocal cords

Type IV thyroplasty

Lengthening of vocal cords

questions.text: During a mass casualty incident in a densely populated area, a triage system is implemented to manage the influx of patients effectively . Which among the following is not a feature of blue color coding in the triage system of disaster management?

questions.correct_answer: B. Victims must be helped within 0 to 6 hours

Correct Option B - 

Red

  • High priority

  • Victims must be helped within 0 to 6 hours.

  • Require immediate resuscitation of life-saving surgery

  • E.g. – hemothorax or pneumothorax

Yellow or Blue

  • Medium priority

  • Victims must be helped within 6 to 24 hours

  • They can wait up to 24 hours

Green

  • Low priority

  • These victims are Ambulatory

  • They can move with minor injuries

Black

  • Least priority

  • They are either dead or moribund (likely to die)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true for a patient with hematuria and the given renal histopathology slide? 1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction. 2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12, 4, and 1 are responsible. 3. Gross findings on the kidney show flea-bitten appearance. 4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 1,2 and 3 are tru

Feature

Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

Alternative Names

Post Infectious Glomerulonephritis / Acute Proliferative Glomerulonephritis

Causative Agent

Streptococcus Pyogenes (Group A β Hemolytic streptococcus): Strain 12, 4, 1

Incubation Period

1-4 weeks

Clinical Features

Initially the patient develops sore throat or Skin infection due to Streptococcus leading to Type 3 Hypersensitivity reaction which in turn causes PSGN (Cola coloured urine)

Blood Tests
  • Antibodies: Anti-DNAse B (preferred), Antistreptolysin O (ASO)
  • Transient Hypocomplementemia blood test (Transient decrease in C3)

Gross Finding

Flea-bitten appearance

Light Microscopy
  • Increase in endothelial cells.
  • Increase in mesangial cells.
  • Increase in neutrophils.
  • Increase in macrophages.
  • Hypercellular glomeruli noted

Immunofluorescence

Starry sky appearance

Treatment

Antibiotics (usually penicillin or other appropriate antibiotics to eliminate the streptococcal infection)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the definition of steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period

options.label: C
options.text: More than 3 relapses in any 12 months

options.label: D
options.text: Two consecutive relapses within 3 weeks of its discontinuation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid th

Remission

Urine albumin nil or trace (or proteinuria <4 mg/m2/h) for 3 consecutive early morning specimens.

Relapse

Urine albumin 3+ or 4+ (or proteinuria > 40 mg/m2/h) for 3 consecutive early morning specimens, after having been in remission previously.

Frequent relapses

Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period or more than 3 relapses in any 12 months.

Steroid dependence

Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy or within 14 days of its discontinuation.

Steroid resistance

Absence of remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg/d for 4 weeks.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with a history of recurrent, unilateral nasal obstruction and episodes of profuse epistaxis over the past several months. On examination, the following is observed: What sign is likely to be seen on this patient's CECT scan due to erosion of the wedge of the pterygoid?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Chopstick sig

Role of Plain X-ray/CT scan
  • Holmann Miller sign: Anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Hondusa's sign: increase in distance between maxillary sinus and mandible on CTscan.
  • Opacification of sphenoid sinus.

Role of CECT scan
  • CTdiagnosis is based on two constant features:

i. Mass in the nose and pterygopalatine fossa.

ii. Erosion of bone behind the sphenopalatine foramen at the root of the pterygoid plate.

  • When the wedge of pterygoid is eroded so the medial and lateral pterygoid plate look like a separate plate, that is called Chopstick sign.

Role of MRI
  • MRI accesses the relation of the tumor to the critical structures such as the internal carotid artery, cavernous sinus and pituitary gland.
  • Recurrent and residual tumors are the best appreciated on the MRI

questions.text: Which of the following endocrine effects is associated with the use of lithium?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Hypoth

 

LITHIUM

Lithium

Mood stabilizer

Absorption

Completely absorbed after oral administration

Plasma half-life

Initially 1-3 days, 2-4 days after long-term use

Indications

Manic episodes, bipolar depression, maintenance therapy, adjuvant in certain disorders

Side effects

Neurological, Endocrine, Renal, Dermatological, Others

Teratogenic effects

Risk of Ebstein's anomaly of tricuspid valve in exposed fetus

Drug interactions
  • ↑ Lithium concentration: Thiazide diuretics, K-sparing diuretics, ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs (except aspirin, sulindac)
  • ↓ Lithium concentration: Loop diuretics, osmotics , xanthine, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Checking lithium levels

Blood sample taken 12 hours 30 minutes after the last dose

Lithium levels
  • Therapeutic range - 0.5-1.5 mEq/L
  • In acute mania - 1 - 1.5 mEq/L
  • Maintenance - 0.6 - 1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxicity - > 1.5 mEq/L

Risk of lithium toxicity

Exceeding recommended dosage, renal impairment, drug interactions

Symptoms of toxicity

 

 

 
  • Mild to moderate: GI symptoms, CNS symptoms
  • Moderate to severe: GI and CNS symptoms
  • Severe: Generalized convulsions, renal failure

Treatment for toxicity

Stop lithium, correct hydration, removal of unabsorbed lithium, hemodialysis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female named Sarah recently survived a severe car accident. She was trapped in the wreckage for several hours before being rescued. Post traumatic stress disorder

Definition

Stress disorder occurring after exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence. Symptoms last more than a month.

Symptoms

MAHI: Mood and cognitive symptoms, Avoidance, Hyperarousal, Intrusion symptoms.

Delayed Expression

Symptoms may appear after 6 months of trauma.

Structural Changes

PTSD is associated with structural changes in the Hippocampus and Amygdala.

Risk Factors

Female gender, Childhood trauma, Poor social support, Stressful life changes, Family history of psychiatric illness, Certain personality disorder traits.

Treatment

Pharmacotherapy (SSRIs), Psychotherapy (CBT, EMDR).

Complex PTSD

New diagnosis in ICD 11, associated with repetitive and severe stressors. Additional symptoms include affect regulation problems and difficulties in relationships.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is required for the diagnosis of definite Meniere's disease?

questions.correct_answer: B. More than 2 episodes of spontaneous vertigo lasting for more than 20 minutes
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B- More than 2 episodes of spontaneous vertigo lasting for more than 20 minu

Definition

Symptoms

Certain Meniere’s disease

Definite Meniere’s disease plus histopathologic confirmation

Definite Meniere’s disease
  • >/=2 definitive spontaneous episodes of vertigo 20 min or longer. Audiometrically documented hearing loss on at least 1 occasion. Tinnitus or aural fullness in the treated ear.
  • Other causes excluded

Probable Meniere’s disease
  • One definitive episode of vertigo
  • Audiometrically documented hearing loss on at least 1 occasion
  • Tinnitus or aural fullness in the treated ear
  • Other causes excluded

Possible Meniere’s disease
  • Episodic vertigo without documented hearing loss, or Sensorineural hearing loss fluctuating or fixed, with disequilibrium but non – episodic
  • Other causes excluded

X-rays show multiple fractures. A whole-body CT shows a bilateral pulmonary contusion with small hemothorax, a renal contusion , and multiple pelvic fractures . Progressively, the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable . Three units of packed erythrocytes are given together with 1 g of tranexamic acid and 1000 ml hydroxyethyl starch. Laboratory parameter analysis from the blood sample drawn at admission confirms coagulopathy associated with moderate metabolic acidosis . What is the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient should be prepared for damage control surgery

options.label: B
options.text: The patient should be hemodynamically stable for any operative procedure; hence aggressive resuscitation is recommended

options.label: C
options.text: Coagulopathy has to be corrected as a part of resuscitation, and then operative control of hemorrhage & contamination is performed

options.label: D
options.text: If hemodynamic stability is achieved, conservative management is enough for this patient

questions.correct_answer: A. The patient should be prepared for damage control surgery
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - The patient should be prepared for damage control surg

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of Allopurinol , and in which condition is its derivative Oxypurinol commonly used?

options.label: A
options.text: Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, and Oxypurinol is primarily used in acute gout.

options.label: B
options.text: Allopurinol promotes uric acid excretion, and Oxypurinol is commonly used in Chagas disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Allopurinol decreases purine synthesis, and Oxypurinol is prescribed primarily for Lesch Nyhan Syndrome.

options.label: D
options.text: Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, and Oxypurinol is given when the patient is allergic to Allopurinol.

questions.correct_answer: D. Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, and Oxypurinol is given when the patient is allergic to Allopurinol.
